presetChoice.explainer: In Dungeons & Dragons, a character preset is a pre-designed character with predefined race, class, abilities, and background. Players might opt for a character preset to save time and simplify the character creation process, making it easier to jump into the game.

gettingStarted.welcome: Welcome to the D&D Character Creator – Crafting heroes made easy.
gettingStarted.explainer:
Our tool is designed to make character creation a breeze while ensuring your character is unique and well-defined. Wiz-Rad guides you through a series of questions that help you determine your character's race, class, ability scores, personality, and equipment. 

   With Wiz-Rad, you won't need to flip through rulebooks or worry about all the details. Instead, you'll focus on shaping your character's story and personality. 

Your character sheet will be filled out automatically as you answer questions about the role you want to play.

explainer.details:
The race you choose influences your character's physical traits, abilities, and cultural background, shaping how you interact with the game world and your role within it. For example, being a dwarf might make you more resistant to poison, or being an elf could grant you keen senses, all of which can impact your role in different situations.

Race is by no means a restrictive attribute. While you may receive certain bonuses depending on the race you choose, choosing your class will have a much greater impact on your playstyle.

q1.q: Do you want your character to be short or tall?

Short: Those known for their shorter stature and a hardiness, making them well-suited for close combat and physical challenges. They often excel in strength and resilience, making them resilient warriors. Their smaller size doesn't hinder their capabilities; instead, it enhances their skills and allows them to adapt well to various physical tasks.
Tall: Taller and more agile characters can possess grace, nimbleness, and agility, excelling in finesse-based tasks and ranged combat. This group has a wide range of characters with unique abilities and backgrounds, making them versatile and adaptable to different situations.

q2.q: Do you want to play as both a human/half-human?

Human/Half-Human: Characters with more human-like qualities in D&D tend to exhibit a balance of physical and mental attributes. They often adapt well to diverse roles and situations.
Something Different: Individuals with unique qualities that possess traits which deviate from the typical human characteristics. These non-human attributes often come with distinct abilities and backgrounds, setting them apart from the common human experience.

See in the dark: Darkvision is a powerful ability that allows the player to see in the dark. Many cnosider it one of the most important abilities.
Breath fire (or other elements): Elemental attacks can be devistating and tactical attacks that give you the upper hand in certain situations

q4.q: Do you destroy your foes up close or from afar?

Fire: Fire-related abilities involve the use of flames or fiery breath to deal damage. Such powers are often associated with an affinity for magical energy and can suit classes like Wizards and Sorcerers.
Poison: Poison-based abilities typically revolve around the release of toxic gas that harms opponents. These capabilities align with classes like Druids and Rangers, which draw power from nature and are connected to the elements and ecosystems.
Cold: Cold abilities often involve the emission of freezing breath. The specifics of these powers aren't mentioned, but they're connected to the element of cold.

q6.q: Choose a breath weapon: Choose a breath weapon:

Acid: Acid-based abilities allow for the expulsion of corrosive acid, which can be used as a breath weapon. Like Fire abilities, Acid powers are often related to manipulating magical energy and can align with classes like Wizards and Sorcerers.
Lightning: Lightning abilities include the release of bolts of lightning. These powers have a connection to nature and the elements and are compatible with classes like Druids and Rangers, which draw their power from the natural world.
Fire: Fire-related abilities involve the use of flames or fiery breath to deal damage. Such powers are often associated with an affinity for magical energy and can suit classes like Wizards and Sorcerers.

response.title: Based on your response, we've handpicked a selection of races for your character:

Dwarf.Hill Dwarf:
Hill Dwarf

As a hill dwarf, you have keen senses, deep intuition, and remarkable resilience. The gold dwarves of Faenln in their mighty southern kingdom are hill dwarves, as are the exiled Neidar and the debased Klar of Krynn in the Dragonlance setting.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Dwarven Toughness: Your hit point maximum increases by 1, and it increases by 1 every time you gain a level.
Dwarf.Mountain Dwarf:
Mountain Dwarf

As a mountain dwarf, you're strong and hardy, accustomed to a difficult life in rugged terrain. You're probably on the tall side (for a dwarf), and tend toward lighter coloration. The shield dwarves of northern Faerun, as well as the ruling Hylar clan and the noble Daewar clan of Dragonlance, are mountain dwarves.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2.

Dwarven Armor Training: You have proficiency with light and medium armor.

Elf.High Elf:
High Elf

As a high elf, you have a keen mind and a mastery of at least the basics of magic. In many of the worlds of D&D, there are two kinds of high elves. One type (which includes the gray elves and valley elves of Greyhawk, the Silvanesti of Dragonlance, and the sun elves of the Forgotten Realms) is haughty and reclusive, believing themselves to be superior to non-elves and even other elves. The other type (including the high elves of Greyhawk, the Qualinesti of Dragonlance, and the moon elves of the Forgotten Realms) is more common and friendly, often encountered among humans and other races.

Ability Score Increase: Your Intelligence score increases by 1.

Elf Weapon Training: You have proficiency with the longsword, shortsword, shortbow, and longbow.

Cantrip: You know one cantrip of your choice from the wizard spell list. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for it.

Extra Language: You can speak, read, and write one extra language of your choice.
Elf.Wood Elf:
Wood Elf

As a wood elf, you have keen senses and intuition, and your fleet feet carry you quickly and stealthily through your native forests. This category includes the wild elves (grugach) of Greyhawk and the Kagonesli of Dragonlance, as well as the races called wood elves in Greyhawk and the Forgotten Realms. In Faerun, wood elves (also called wild elves, green elves, or forest elves) are reclusive and distrustful of non-elves.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Elf Weapon Training: You have proficiency with the longsword, shortsword, shortbow, and longbow.

Fleet of Foot: Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet.

Mask of the Wild: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.
Elf.Dark Elf (Drow):
Dark Elf (Drow)

Descended from an earlier subrace of dark-skinned elves, the drow were banished from the surface world for following the goddess Lolth down the path to evil and corruption. Now they have built their own civilization in the depths of the Underdark, patterned after the Way of Lolth. Also called dark elves, the drow have black skin that resembles polished obsidian and stark white or pale yellow hair. They commonly have very pale eyes (so pale as to be mistaken for white) in shades of lilac, silver, pink, red, and blue. They tend to be smaller and thinner than most elves.

Drow adventurers are rare, and the race does not exist in all worlds. Check with your Dungeon Master to see if you can play a drow character.

Ability Score Increase: Your Charisma score increases by 1.

Superior Darkvision: Your darkvision has a radius of 120 feet.

Sunlight Sensitivity: You have disadvantage on attack rolls and on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight when you, the target of your attack, or whatever you are trying to perceive is in direct sunlight.

Drow Magic: You know the dancing lights cantrip. When you reach 3rd level, you can cast the faerie fire spell once per day. When you reach 5th level, you can also cast the darkness spell once per day. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

Drow Weapon Training: You have proficiency with rapiers, shortswords, and hand crossbows.

Halfling.Lightfoot Halfling:
Lightfoot Halfling

Lightfoot halflings are more prone to wanderlust than other halflings and often dwell alongside other races or take up a nomadic life. In the world of Greyhawk, these halflings are called hairfeet or tallfellows. They are known to be affable and get along well with others. In the Forgotten Realms, lightfoot halflings have spread the farthest and thus are the most common variety.

Ability Score Increase: Your Charisma score increases by 1.

Naturally Stealthy: You can attempt to hide even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.
Halfling.Stout Halfling:
Stout Halfling

Stout halflings are hardier than average and have some resistance to poison. Some say that stouts have dwarven blood. In the Forgotten Realms, these halflings are called stronghearts, and they're most common in the south.

Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 1.

Stout Resilience: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.

Gnome.Forest Gnome:
Forest Gnome

Forest gnomes are rare and secretive, gathering in hidden communities in sylvan forests. They have a natural knack for illusion, quickness, and stealth. These gnomes tend to be friendly with other good-spirited woodland folk, and they regard elves and good fey as their most important allies. Forest gnomes also befriend small forest animals and rely on them for information about threats that might prowl their lands.

Ability Score Increase: Your Dexterity score increases by 1.

Natural Illusionist: You know the minor illusion cantrip. Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for it.

Speak with Small Beasts: Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas with Small or smaller beasts. Forest gnomes love animals and often keep squirrels, badgers, rabbits, moles, woodpeckers, and other creatures as beloved pets.
Gnome.Rock Gnome:
Rock Gnome

Most gnomes in the worlds of D&D are rock gnomes, known for their natural inventiveness and hardiness. They are particularly skilled in tinkering with devices and gadgets. In the Dragonlance setting, the tinker gnomes belong to this subrace.

Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 1.

Artificer's Lore: Whenever you make an Intelligence (History) check related to magic items, alchemical objects, or technological devices, you can add twice your proficiency bonus, instead of any proficiency bonus you normally apply.

Tinker: You have proficiency with artisan's tools (tinker's tools) and can use them to create various clockwork devices, such as clockwork toys, fire starters, or music boxes.

alignment.description: Alignment guides a character's decisions and role-playing, influencing their behavior and interactions within the game world. It's a tool for players to define their character's beliefs and values, helping to shape their role-playing experience and relationships with other characters and NPCs. However, alignment is flexible and may evolve as the character's story unfolds, allowing for dynamic character development.

options.Lawful Good: Principled and compassionate, guided by a strict moral code for the greater good.
options.Neutral Good: Altruistic and kind, valuing goodness and empathy without rigid rules.
options.Chaotic Good: Rebellious champions of freedom and kindness, often defying authority.
options.Lawful Neutral: Upholds order and society, focusing on rules and structure over morality.
options.True Neutral: Balanced and impartial, avoiding extremes and embracing nature's balance.
options.Chaotic Neutral: Unpredictable and self-interested, cherishing personal freedom above all.
options.Lawful Evil: Ruthlessly ambitious, using structure and laws to achieve dark goals.
options.Neutral Evil: Self-serving and ruthless, driven by personal gain with no moral qualms.
options.Chaotic Evil: Chaotic and destructive, driven by violence and chaos for its own sake.

misc.race: Every character has a lineage. The race you are assigned contributes to your characters identity and influences the abilities you possess.
misc.class:
Class broadly describes a character’s vocation and the tactics the character is likely to employ when exploring, fighting and negotiating. 

    Classes also determine the benefits you will receive. We will choose a class that receives benefits based on your preferred playstyle.
misc.ability scores: Much of what your character can do is determined by your ability scores. The six abilities are Strength, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.
misc.personality: Once you have the basic game aspects of your character, you'll need to consider who your character is as a person. You'll give them a name, an alignment and background. Keep this in mind when answering questions.
misc.equipment: With a good idea of who your character is, you can choose what they will need on their adventure. Equipment includes armor, weapons, gold and useful tools.
misc.character sheet: A character sheet is used in tabletop role-playing games, like Dungeons & Dragons, to record and organize a player's character information. It includes details such as a character's name, race, class, abilities, skills, equipment, and backstory. Character sheets are essential for tracking a character's progress, abilities, and decisions throughout the game, serving as a reference point for players and game masters during gameplay.
misc.cultural background: A character's cultural background in games like Dungeons & Dragons affects their personality, abilities, and role-playing interactions, adding depth to the narrative and influencing their alignment and moral choices. It contributes to worldbuilding and enriches the game's storytelling experience.
misc.bonuses: For example, playing as a dwarf might provide bonuses to resilience or Constitution, while selecting a wizard class can grant bonuses related to spellcasting and intelligence. These racial and class-based bonuses can influence your character's strengths, weaknesses, and overall playstyle within the game, but you won't be restrcited to a playstyle based only on race.
